hypotheses: H1: In democratic countries, higher political polarization is associated with smaller government size.
H2: In undemocratic countries, political polarization is not significantly related to government size.
claim.statement: Increased political polarization leads to smaller government size in democratic countries.

data.source: World Values Survey (WVS) merged with World Bank/IMF government consumption data compiled by Gwartney and Lawson
data.wave_or_subset: WVS waves up to 2005; government consumption averaged 2003–2005
data.sample_size: Approximately 1,000 respondents in each of 83 countries; analytical sample 74 countries with complete data
data.unit_of_analysis: Country (survey responses aggregated to country-level polarization measures)
data.access_details: Publicly available via World Values Survey and World Bank databases
data.notes: Polarization calculated as the standard deviation (and alternative indices) of answers to four economic-policy questions (EQUALITY, PRIVATE, GOV, COMP)

method.description: Cross-country observational analysis linking survey-based measures of political polarization to government size measures while controlling for economic, demographic, and institutional factors.
steps: Download WVS microdata and select four economic-policy questions.
Compute country-level polarization (standard deviation and alternative indices) for each question.
Merge polarization indicators with country-level covariates (GDP per capita, trade openness, demographic structure, colonial origin, democracy index, etc.) and government consumption data (GOVCONS).
Construct three regression specifications (basic, short, long) with increasing sets of control variables.
Estimate OLS regressions of government size on polarization for all countries, and separately for weak and strong democracies (based on Polity IV index).

Perform robustness checks: alternative government size metric (transfers & subsidies), different polarization indices, interaction terms with fragmentation indices, and controls for income inequality.
method.models: Cross-sectional OLS regression with heteroscedasticity-robust standard errors
method.outcome_variable: Government consumption as a share of total consumption (GOVCONS), alternatively government transfers & subsidies as share of GDP
method.independent_variables: Political polarization indices derived from WVS responses (EQUALITY, PRIVATE, GOV, COMP standard deviations; Esteban-Ray index; bipolarization index)
method.control_variables: GDP per capita, trade openness, demographic shares, colonial origin dummies, democracy index (Polity IV), OECD membership, ethnic/religious fractionalization, trust, press freedom, corruption, property rights, voter turnout

results.summary: Across 74 countries, higher electorate polarization is strongly associated with smaller government consumption, but only in strong democracies. In weak or non-democracies the association is negligible. A one-standard-deviation increase in polarization predicts roughly a 4-percentage-point reduction in government consumption in strong democracies. Findings are robust to numerous controls, alternative polarization metrics, and alternative spending measures.

metadata.original_paper_title: Political Polarization and the Size of Government
